values.title: Add cppcheck rules to prevent identifiers starting with _[A-Z]

summary.html:
@sherm1 pointed out in pull request #82 that identifiers shouldn't start with an underscore followed by a capital letter (_[A-Z]). This includes functions and header guards. So I wrote cppcheck rules for both of these cases (failure confirmed here) and fixed them as necessary.

In d305336, I added IGN_SQRT2 so _USE_MATH_DEFINES isn't necessary.

I also fixed the header guards as necessary.

values.description:
The reason this is so big is because cppcheck wanted an `explicit` constructor for `Angle::Angle(double)`. This caused compilation failures because we were using implicit conversion from double to `Angle`.

So, I added proper operator overloads for doubles, and also added two literal functions:

1. `_ign_deg`
2. `_ign_rad`

This is the first time I've define a literal, so suggestions are welcome.
values.title: Fix xenial code check

summary.raw:
The reason this is so big is because cppcheck wanted an `explicit` constructor for `Angle::Angle(double)`. This caused compilation failures because we were using implicit conversion from double to `Angle`.

So, I added proper operator overloads for doubles, and also added two literal functions:

1. `_ign_deg`
2. `_ign_rad`

This is the first time I've define a literal, so suggestions are welcome.
summary.html:
The reason this is so big is because cppcheck wanted an explicit constructor for Angle::Angle(double). This caused compilation failures because we were using implicit conversion from double to Angle.

So, I added proper operator overloads for doubles, and also added two literal functions:

  1. _ign_deg
  2. _ign_rad

This is the first time I've define a literal, so suggestions are welcome.

values.description:
These are some small adjustments to the numerics of the inertia resizing helper functions.

* In c1cfec6, I found a corner-case (v=0) that wasn't handled and would generate `NaN`s. So I added a test and fixed the corner-case

* While debugging inertia resizing in gazebo, there were some bugs in handling the rotations properly for non-diagonal matrices due to re-ordering of the principal moments. It was easier to debug if I caused principal moments to always be sorted. This is actually very easy to enable by negating the tolerance parameter (ie. `-1e-6` instead of `1e-6`) with some small changes to the code in 4c646f6. I also added some tests for sending negative tolerances.
values.title: Inertia resizing: numerical adjustments

summary.raw:
These are some small adjustments to the numerics of the inertia resizing helper functions.

* In c1cfec6, I found a corner-case (v=0) that wasn't handled and would generate `NaN`s. So I added a test and fixed the corner-case

* While debugging inertia resizing in gazebo, there were some bugs in handling the rotations properly for non-diagonal matrices due to re-ordering of the principal moments. It was easier to debug if I caused principal moments to always be sorted. This is actually very easy to enable by negating the tolerance parameter (ie. `-1e-6` instead of `1e-6`) with some small changes to the code in 4c646f6. I also added some tests for sending negative tolerances.
summary.html:
These are some small adjustments to the numerics of the inertia resizing helper functions.

  • In c1cfec6, I found a corner-case (v=0) that wasn't handled and would generate NaNs. So I added a test and fixed the corner-case

  • While debugging inertia resizing in gazebo, there were some bugs in handling the rotations properly for non-diagonal matrices due to re-ordering of the principal moments. It was easier to debug if I caused principal moments to always be sorted. This is actually very easy to enable by negating the tolerance parameter (ie. -1e-6 instead of 1e-6) with some small changes to the code in 4c646f6. I also added some tests for sending negative tolerances.

values.description:
This PR adds helper functions for setting a `MassMatrix3` object based on the geometry of some simple shapes (box, sphere, and cylinder aligned with z axis). There is also a function called `EquivalentBox` that returns the shape and orientation of a box with equivalent inertia to the current `MassMatrix3` object. Note that the orientation is not unique due to box symmetry.

This also includes a few small numerical enhancements to the `MassMatrix3` algorithms that have been split into pull request #109 to simplify the review process. The diff for this PR will be smaller after that one is merged.

If you want to test this pull request with gazebo, use [gazebo branch inertia_vis](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/compare/inertia_vis%0Dgazebo7), which uses these functions to rescale the inertia of simple shapes when the resize tool is used from the simulation window. It also replaces a few instances of inertia calculations.
values.title: MassMatrix3: helper functions for simple shapes

summary.raw:

There is also a function called `EquivalentBox` that returns the shape and orientation of a box with equivalent inertia to the current `MassMatrix3` object. Note that the orientation is not unique due to box symmetry.

This also includes a few small numerical enhancements to the `MassMatrix3` algorithms that have been split into pull request #109 to simplify the review process. The diff for this PR will be smaller after that one is merged.

If you want to test this pull request with gazebo, use [gazebo branch inertia_vis](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/compare/inertia_vis%0Dgazebo7), which uses these functions to rescale the inertia of simple shapes when the resize tool is used from the simulation window. It also replaces a few instances of inertia calculations.
summary.html:
This PR adds helper functions for setting a MassMatrix3 object based on the geometry of some simple shapes (box, sphere, and cylinder aligned with z axis). There is also a function called EquivalentBox that returns the shape and orientation of a box with equivalent inertia to the current MassMatrix3 object. Note that the orientation is not unique due to box symmetry.

This also includes a few small numerical enhancements to the MassMatrix3 algorithms that have been split into pull request #109 to simplify the review process. The diff for this PR will be smaller after that one is merged.

If you want to test this pull request with gazebo, use gazebo branch inertia_vis, which uses these functions to rescale the inertia of simple shapes when the resize tool is used from the simulation window. It also replaces a few instances of inertia calculations.

values.title: fix for issue #46, missing operator= that assigns a Matrix3d from Quaterniond

values.description:
This PR introduces a new class `Inertial` that stores a `MassMatrix3` object along with a `Pose` offset that represents the pose of the center of mass reference frame relative to a base frame. This class will be a replacement for the [gazebo::physics::Inertial class](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/d34567662a9/gazebo/physics/Inertial.hh) (see issue #32).

This PR introduces the basic class components (Constructors, Get/Set, `==` operators, etc) and a function `MOI()` that returns the moment of inertia matrix rotated into the base frame. There are tests with 100% coverage (verified locally).
values.title: New Inertial class: MassMatrix3 with pose offset (#32)

summary.raw:
This PR introduces a new class `Inertial` that stores a `MassMatrix3` object along with a `Pose` offset that represents the pose of the center of mass reference frame relative to a base frame. This class will be a replacement for the [gazebo::physics::Inertial class](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/d34567662a9/gazebo/physics/Inertial.hh) (see issue #32).

This PR introduces the basic class components (Constructors, Get/Set, `==` operators, etc) and a function `MOI()` that returns the moment of inertia matrix rotated into the base frame. There are tests with 100% coverage (verified locally).
summary.html:
This PR introduces a new class Inertial that stores a MassMatrix3 object along with a Pose offset that represents the pose of the center of mass reference frame relative to a base frame. This class will be a replacement for the gazebo::physics::Inertial class (see issue #32).

This PR introduces the basic class components (Constructors, Get/Set, == operators, etc) and a function MOI() that returns the moment of inertia matrix rotated into the base frame. There are tests with 100% coverage (verified locally).

values.title: Fix xenial code check and some style

values.description:
This PR introduces the ability to combine inertial properties of different objects, returning the equivalent inertial properties as if the objects were welded together.

The calculation is as follows:

1. Add the masses: `new_mass = mass1 + mass2`
2. Compute the new center of mass location: `pose = mass1*pose1 + mass2*pose2`
3. Add the moment of inertias in the base frame: `MOI = MOI1 + MOI2`
4. Parallel axis theorem: account for offset of each mass from new center of mass (see code)

I also fixed a code_check complaint in `Plane.hh` and added a default value to the `Quaternion` argument in the `SetFromBox` functions, which allows that function to be called more concisely when no rotation is desired ([api / abi is fine](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_math-abichecker-any_to_any-xenial-amd64/6/)).
values.title: Combine inertial properties using + operator

summary.raw:
This PR introduces the ability to combine inertial properties of different objects, returning the equivalent inertial properties as if the objects were welded together.

The calculation is as follows:

1. Add the masses: `new_mass = mass1 + mass2`
2. Compute the new center of mass location: `pose = mass1*pose1 + mass2*pose2`
3. Add the moment of inertias in the base frame: `MOI = MOI1 + MOI2`
4. Parallel axis theorem: account for offset of each mass from new center of mass (see code)

I also fixed a code_check complaint in `Plane.hh` and added a default value to the `Quaternion` argument in the `SetFromBox` functions, which allows that function to be called more concisely when no rotation is desired ([api / abi is fine](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_math-abichecker-any_to_any-xenial-amd64/6/)).
summary.html:
This PR introduces the ability to combine inertial properties of different objects, returning the equivalent inertial properties as if the objects were welded together.

The calculation is as follows:

  1. Add the masses: new_mass = mass1 + mass2
  2. Compute the new center of mass location: pose = mass1*pose1 + mass2*pose2
  3. Add the moment of inertias in the base frame: MOI = MOI1 + MOI2
  4. Parallel axis theorem: account for offset of each mass from new center of mass (see code)

I also fixed a code_check complaint in Plane.hh and added a default value to the Quaternion argument in the SetFromBox functions, which allows that function to be called more concisely when no rotation is desired (api / abi is fine).

values.description:
This enables to "parse" the `CMakeLists.txt` file and extract the project name. Relying on variable expansion would make this way more complicated.

It also restores the meaning of `PROJECT_NAME` to contain the project name and uses a custom variable `PROJECT_NAME_WITH_VERSION` instead.

values.description:
The inertial class has two sets of rotations that affect the moment of inertia matrix:

* the `Inertial::pose` rotation
* the rotation embedded in the MassMatrix

This PR adds functions for setting either of these rotations without affecting the moment of inertia in the base frame accessible from `Inertial::MOI()`.

* `SetInertialRotation`: sets the pose rotation and multiplies the matrices accordingly
* `SetMassMatrixRotation`: sets the rotation embedded in the MassMatrix. If an identity quaternion is passed, it will diagonalize the MassMatrix. One caveat is that all inertia matrices are symmetric with rotations of +-PI around any axis, and there are even more symmetries if there are repeated principal moments, so you aren't guaranteed to get the same rotation from `PrincipalAxesOffset` that you gave to this function (unless you diagonalize).

Both functions have tests. I also found a bug in `MassMatrix3` when calling `PrincipalAxesOffset` on a multiple of the identity matrix with a negative tolerance. I've added test coverage and fixed the bug.
values.title: Set Inertial Rotations

summary.raw:
The inertial class has two sets of rotations that affect the moment of inertia matrix:

* the `Inertial::pose` rotation
* the rotation embedded in the MassMatrix

This PR adds functions for setting either of these rotations without affecting the moment of inertia in the base frame accessible from `Inertial::MOI()`.

* `SetInertialRotation`: sets the pose rotation and multiplies the matrices accordingly
* `SetMassMatrixRotation`: sets the rotation embedded in the MassMatrix. If an identity quaternion is passed, it will diagonalize the MassMatrix. One caveat is that all inertia matrices are symmetric with rotations of +-PI around any axis, and there are even more symmetries if there are repeated principal moments, so you aren't guaranteed to get the same rotation from `PrincipalAxesOffset` that you gave to this function (unless you diagonalize).

Both functions have tests. I also found a bug in `MassMatrix3` when calling `PrincipalAxesOffset` on a multiple of the identity matrix with a negative tolerance. I've added test coverage and fixed the bug.
summary.html:
The inertial class has two sets of rotations that affect the moment of inertia matrix:

  • the Inertial::pose rotation
  • the rotation embedded in the MassMatrix

This PR adds functions for setting either of these rotations without affecting the moment of inertia in the base frame accessible from Inertial::MOI().

  • SetInertialRotation: sets the pose rotation and multiplies the matrices accordingly
  • SetMassMatrixRotation: sets the rotation embedded in the MassMatrix. If an identity quaternion is passed, it will diagonalize the MassMatrix. One caveat is that all inertia matrices are symmetric with rotations of +-PI around any axis, and there are even more symmetries if there are repeated principal moments, so you aren't guaranteed to get the same rotation from PrincipalAxesOffset that you gave to this function (unless you diagonalize).

Both functions have tests. I also found a bug in MassMatrix3 when calling PrincipalAxesOffset on a multiple of the identity matrix with a negative tolerance. I've added test coverage and fixed the bug.

values.description:
Remove exceptions from ign-math. This will make it easier to write a C (and scripting language) wrappers for this library.

We were also using exceptions as a way to communicate errors, which is not ideal. This pull request clamps a few index values where appropriate, and produces error values in other cases.
values.title: Remove exceptions

summary.raw:
Remove exceptions from ign-math. This will make it easier to write a C (and scripting language) wrappers for this library.

We were also using exceptions as a way to communicate errors, which is not ideal. This pull request clamps a few index values where appropriate, and produces error values in other cases.
summary.html:
Remove exceptions from ign-math. This will make it easier to write a C (and scripting language) wrappers for this library.

We were also using exceptions as a way to communicate errors, which is not ideal. This pull request clamps a few index values where appropriate, and produces error values in other cases.
